*** Pending ***.description: Natural Disaster warnings typically operate on a tiered system (advisory/watch/warning) issued before events occur as a warning and to encourage preparation. National meteorological services like the US National Weather Service (NWS), USGS, FEMA, NOAH, issue these alerts based on predictive models, with watches signaling possible threats (e.g., tornado watch = conditions favorable within 48 hours) and warnings confirming imminent danger (e.g., tornado warning = radar-detected funnel within minutes). Emergency agencies then amplify these alerts via cell broadcasts, sirens, and radio, leveraging lead times that range from hours for hurricanes (NHC warnings at 36-hour mark) to seconds for earthquakes (USGS ShakeAlert system). Crucially, all official warnings are proactive.

*** Ongoing ***.description: Ongoing denotes the active phase of an emergency during which hazardous conditions are dynamically manifesting and changing.

*** Aftermath ***.description: Concluded or Aftermath denotes the post-impact phase of an emergency during which the primary hazard has ceased, yet unverified environments retain lethal secondary threats—requiring systematic hazard validation.

*** Emotional ***.description: Emotional reactions in emergencies trigger impulsive decisions that worsen outcomes, such as panicked evacuations without supplies or ignoring critical instructions. This undermines coordination, causing delayed responses and misallocated resources—directly increasing preventable casualties.

*** Positive Actions ***.description: Positive actions by thoughtful individuals in emergencies instinctively override panic with disciplined cognition: assessing threats before acting, conserving energy for critical tasks, and prioritizing verifiable facts over rumors—transforming chaos into calculated survival.

*** Resistance ***.description: Resistance in emergencies manifests as defiant refusal to adapt—ignoring evacuation orders to protect property, arguing with responders about protocols, or spreading counterproductive rumors that fracture collective action—transforming individual stubbornness into communal catastrophe.

*** Negative Actions ***.description: Negative public responses involving harmful or disruptive actions that hinder emergency management.

*** Full Operations ***.description: Station Status describes the operational condition of communication stations during an emergency, such as fully or partially functional.

*** Partial Operations ***.description: Current condition indicates the environmental or safety state at the station, such as normal or unsafe conditions.

*** Limited Operations ***.description: Personal/Family Response covers actions taken by individuals or families, like sheltering in place or evacuating.

*** Station Logistics ***.description: Shelter/supplies addresses damage levels and needs for resources or transportation at the station.

C.name: Normal conditions - little to no impact

D.name: Normal conditions or Not in impact zone

F.name: Sub-optimal conditions or Sheltering in place

G.name: Sub-optimal conditions or On the edge of impact zone

M.name: Severe/Unsafe conditions/In the center of impact zone

*** Health Impacts ***.description: Health Impacts quantify physical harm to populations from disasters, including acute trauma (e.g., crush injuries in quakes), poisoning (chemical spills), infectious outbreaks (flood-contaminated water), and fatalities with a chance of overwhelming triage capacity and spiking mortality when medical systems collapse.

*** Social Impacts ***.description: Social Impacts measure disruptions to community structures, including displacement from homes, forced evacuations, civil unrest from resource scarcity, and economic collapse—potentially destabilizing regions for months if relief and governance fail to adapt quickly.

*** Authority Reaction ***.description: Authority Reaction describes the deployment of official response forces, such as police, National Guard, or military, to manage emergencies, restore order, or secure affected areas. These responses can escalate situations or stabilize them, depending on the scale, coordination, and public perception of the intervention.

*** Economic Impacts ***.description: Infrastructure Impacts involve damage to critical systems like power, transportation, communication, or buildings, crippling response efforts and amplifying secondary effects like economic loss or delayed recovery—potentially paralyzing regions for weeks if not addressed swiftly.

group_descriptions.*** Earthquake ***: Earthquake damage severity escalates predictably across MMI tiers: Low Intensity (I–V) causes perceptible shaking and minor non-structural effects (e.g., rattled objects, cracked plaster) with no building damage. Moderate Intensity (VI–VIII) triggers structural harm—chimney collapses at VI, partial failures in vulnerable structures at VII, and foundation shifts/wall damage at VIII. Extreme Intensity (IX–XII) produces catastrophic destruction: violent shaking (IX) topples well-built buildings, while X–XII causes near-total disintegration, ground ruptures, and infrastructure annihilation. This progression directly informs emergency response protocols and structural safety assessments.
group_descriptions.*** Tornado ***: Tornado damage severity escalates systematically across EF-scale tiers: Weak (EF0–EF1) causes minor structural effects—broken branches, peeled roof surfaces, and damaged gutters—with EF1 lifting roofs off poorly anchored structures. Strong (EF2–EF3) triggers significant destruction: EF2 snaps large trees and rips roofs off well-built homes; EF3 collapses exterior walls, overturns trains, and debarks trees. Violent (EF4–EF5) produces near-total devastation: EF4 flattens well-constructed houses and hurls vehicles airborne; EF5 obliterates reinforced buildings, scours foundations, and distorts skyscrapers—leaving landscapes unrecognizable. This progression directly informs shelter-in-place protocols and structural engineering standards.
group_descriptions.*** Hurricane ***: Hurricane damage severity escalates distinctly across Saffir-Simpson tiers: Minor (Cat 1–2) inflicts non-structural harm—Cat 1 (74–95 mph) damages roofs/siding and topples shallow-rooted trees; Cat 2 (96–110 mph) causes major roof failure, snaps large trees, and triggers extended power outages. Major (Cat 3) (111–129 mph) initiates structural collapse: poorly built homes are destroyed, flooding reaches 4+ ft above ground, and communities face weeks without utilities. Catastrophic (Cat 4–5) (130+ mph) ensures near-total devastation—Cat 4 flattens well-constructed houses with 12+ ft storm surge; Cat 5 (157+ mph) obliterates reinforced structures, scours foundations, and inundates coastlines beyond 18 ft, rendering zones uninhabitable for months (NOAA, 2024). This tiered impact profile dictates mandatory evacuation thresholds and infrastructure resilience requirements.
group_descriptions.*** Other Natural Disasters ***: Natural disasters are those disasters that are not man-made.
group_descriptions.*** Health Impacts ***: Health Impacts quantify physical harm to populations from disasters, including acute trauma (e.g., crush injuries in quakes), poisoning (chemical spills), infectious outbreaks (flood-contaminated water), and fatalities with a chance of overwhelming triage capacity and spiking mortality when medical systems collapse.
group_descriptions.*** Social Impacts ***: Social Impacts measure disruptions to community structures, including displacement from homes, forced evacuations, civil unrest from resource scarcity, and economic collapse—potentially destabilizing regions for months if relief and governance fail to adapt quickly.
group_descriptions.*** Authority Reaction ***: Authority Reaction describes the deployment of official response forces, such as police, National Guard, or military, to manage emergencies, restore order, or secure affected areas. These responses can escalate situations or stabilize them, depending on the scale, coordination, and public perception of the intervention.
